intro: Launaea rueppellii, commonly known as the desert dandelion, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of Africa and the Middle East. It is a perennial shrub that typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, characterized by its hairy stems and lobed, waxy leaves adapted to conserve water. The plant produces small, yellow flowers that bloom in spring, followed by fluffy, white seed heads that aid in wind dispersal. Launaea rueppellii is drought-tolerant and thrives in sandy or rocky soils, making it well-suited for harsh desert environments. It plays a role in stabilizing soil and providing forage for wildlife in its native habitats.
